occurrences.line_text: That was with royall arras richly dight,
Did sit, as yet ashamd, how rude Pan did her dight.
And to her guestes doth bounteous banket dight,
Eftsoones himselfe in glitterand armes he dight,
No gate, but like one, being goodly dight
As faint through heat, or dight to pleasant sin,
And round about it many beds were dight,
Supper was shortly dight and downe they sat,
And her bright armes about her body dight:
And downe againe in her warme bed her dight;
About her selfe she dight, that the young Mayd
Her dolour soone she ceast, and on her dight
There they him laid in easie couch well dight;
The which was all within most richly dight,
With this faire flowre your goodly girlonds dight,
And her loose lockes to dight in order dew,
He fine would dight; sometimes the squirell wild
In his proud furnitures she freshly dight,
Yet tried did adore. Supper was dight;
Was fowly dight, and he of death afeard.
And wings it had with sundry colours dight,
But painted plumes, in goodly order dight,
They both vprose, and to their waies them dight:
Casts off his ragged skin and freshly doth him dight.
Which to auenge, Sir Deuon him did dight,
If he misdid, he on himselfe did dight,
To dight, to welcome him, well as she can:
Till I thereto had all things ready dight.
Gan dight him selfe vnto his wonted sinne;
And did themselues vnto their iourney dight.
And all without were walkes and alleyes dight,
For all the Priests were damzels, in soft linnen dight.
Liues still: and to this feast with Neptunes seed was dight.
He askt, who had that Dame so fouly dight;
Or curst the hand, which did that vengea[n]ce on him dight.
To be a troupe of women warlike dight,
And nimbly did him dight to guide the way
She fiercely towards him her selfe gan dight,
But Artegall him selfe to rest did dight,
And th'Amazon, as best it likt her selfe to dight.
In stead whereof she made him to be dight
But streight her selfe did dight, and armor don;
A raskall rout, with weapons rudely dight.
Was to the battell whilome ready dight.
Kept himselfe still in his straunge armour dight.
And all his armours readie dight that day,
In roiall robes, and many Iewels dight,
Then vp she rose, and on her selfe did dight
Which to prouide, she hath this Castle dight,
And hauing soone his armes about him dight,
Whereof he taking oddes, streight bids him dight
And after hauing them vpon him dight,
That she her selfe had to the iourney dight,
And pleasaunce of the place, the which was dight
About the sad Serena things to dight,
So hauing all things well about her dight,
Then vp they rose, and gan them selues to dight
Vpon checklaton he was straungely dight,
And supper readie dight, they to it fell
Was dighting her, hauing her snowy brest
With his faire mother he him dights to play,
And set in highest seat of dignitee,
Honour and dignitie from her alone,
Doth loose his dignitie and natiue grace.
Therefore he first wore crowne of gold for dignitie.
For their high merits and great dignitie,
To ouerthrow my state and dignitie.
I had, you to reward with greater dignitie.
She was a Ladie of great dignitie,
Them entertayn'd, fit for their dignities,
And euery lincke thereof a step of dignity.
Seekes to subuert her Crowne and dignity,
That in his chauffe he digs the trampled ground,
For to dilate at large, but vrged sore
With boughes and braunches, which did broad dilate
Of diuerse things discourses to dilate,
With that he gan at large to her dilate
Tho gan that shepheard thus for to dilate;
And streightway sent with carefull diligence,
Which long he vsd with carefull diligence,
And when she wakt, he waited diligent,
With onely Talus wayting diligent,
And kept her sheepe with diligent attent,
Hauing of late by diligent inquest,
Of Camphara, and Calamint, and Dill,
To dim the brightnesse of her glorious throne,
Therewith her dim eie-lids she vp gan reare,
Which mingled all with sweate, did dim his eye.
Through the dim shade, that all men might it see:
Doth dim with horrour and deformitie,
That as a cloud doth seeme to dim the skies;
Thrice shined faire, and thrice seem'd dim and wan,
That the dim eyes of my deare Marinell
All suddenly dim woxe the dampish ayre,
Did dim the brightnesse of the welkin round,
That all the rest like lesser lamps did dim:
And cruell rancour dim'd his valorous
Sith shady dampe had dimd the heauens reach,
But now weake age had dimd his candle light.
Th'one to diminish, th'other for to eeke.
Dimmed her former beauties shining ray,
And dimmed sight with pale and deadly hew
Huge flames, that dimmed all the heauens light,
That seemed to outshine the dimmed skye,
The glaunce whereof their dimmed eies would daze,
But quite are dimmed, when she is in place.
Her louely light was dimmed and decayd,
Yet did the cloud make euen that dimmed light
It dimmes the dazed eyen, and daunts the senses quight.
But enuies cloud still dimmeth vertues ray.
And this bright Angels towre quite dims that towre of glas.
Does all their deeds deface, and dims their glories all.
All full of people making troublous din,
Were shronke into his iawes, as he did neuer dine.
Much daunted with that dint, her sence was dazd,
To taste th'vntryed dint of deadly steele;
That deadly dint of steele endanger may:
Ne dint of direfull sword diuide the substance would.
Haue felt the bitter dint of his auenging blade.
With dint of sword, nor push of pointed speare;
That deeper dint therein it would not make;
The deadly dint his dulled senses all dismaid.
They gan abstaine from dint of direfull stroke,
Deadly dismayd, with horrour of that dint
That no enchauntment from his dint might saue;
It seizd in his right side, and there the dint did stay.
But when he stroke most strong, the dint deceiu'd,
Or else with vs by dint of sword approue,
Sith dint of steele his carcas could not quell:
As if that euery dint the ghost would riue
Ne any armour could his dint out ward,
But firmely fixt they were, with dint of sword,
He cared not for dint of sword nor speere,
Inflicts with dint of sword, so sore doth light,
Deepe dinted furrowes in the battred mayle;
So deepely dinted in the driuen clay,
Dinting his brest, had bred his restlesse paine,
Wherein old dints of deepe wounds did remaine,
That Dioclesians fiftie daughters shene
And seuen times dipped in the bitter waue
That themselues dipping in the siluer dew,
Whose clawes were newly dipt in cruddy blood,
An holy water Sprinckle, dipt in deowe,
That all was couered with darknesse dire:
That nought but dire reuenge his anger mote defray.
Out of her poysnous entrails, fraught with dire decay.
Or that your wisedome will direct my thought,
Those could he well direct and streight as line,
How to direct their way in darkenesse wide,
And all their actions to direct aright;
Or succour her, or me direct the way;
That to their willes could them direct aright,
Them selues her footing to direct aright,
That doth his course through Blandford plains direct,
And sent to him a Page, that mote direct his way.
Kept on his course, as he did it direct,
Forthwith directed to that further strand;
His feeble feet directed to the cry;
They came, as Merlin them directed late:
Before directed by his Lord; to th'end
The Damzell straight went, as she was directed,
Directed in, and shewed all the sight:
So being stayd, they her from thence directed
And her swords point directing forward right,
Is falne on you, by heauens hard direction,
T'obay a womans tyrannous direction,
Or good direction, how to enter in,
Which to the gate directly did incline,
To which her steps directly she did frame.
Did not as others wont, directly fly
I would you guyde directly to the place.
But after went directly as he may,
Directs her course vnto one certaine cost,
By that same way the direfull dames doe driue
Ne dint of direfull sword diuide the substance would.
But yet at last, when as the direfull feend
What direfull chance, armd with reuenging fate,
That through the great contagion direfull deadly stunck.
They gan abstaine from dint of direfull stroke,
Direfull impatience, and hart murdring loue;
That darest vew my direfull countenaunce,
But direfull deadly blacke both leafe and bloom,
In those sad waues, which direfull deadly stanke,
That direfull stroke thou dearely shalt aby.
But they to direfull death their groning ghosts did send.
But nought that falles into this direfull deepe,
Their direfull rancour rather did encreasse;
Vpon thee heapt a direfull destinie,
A direfull stench of smoke and sulphure mixt
The direfull distaffe standing in the mid,
Yet still that direfull stroke kept on his way,
Much was he daunted with that direfull stound,
And snatching forth his direfull deadly blade,
Sir Terpin, from her direfull doome acquit,
Echidna is a Monster direfull dred,
And damned to endure this direfull smart,
Them to disable from reuenge aduenturing.
To a great pere; but she did disaccord,
That forced him his shield to disaduaunce:
And vaunted speare eftsoones to disaduaunce,
And all his disaduentures to vnfold;
Still did they striue, and dayly disagree;
Ne euer thing could cause vs disagree:
To stirre vp strife, and do them disagree;
But in bad maner they did disagree:
That curtesie and manhood euer disagree.
For which th'IdÃ¦an Ladies disagreed,
For by degrees they all were disagreed;
Returning, disappointed his desire,
So as she bad, that witch they disaraid,
Both fiercely bent to haue him disaraid;
In ragged robes, and filthy disaray,
Euery of which did loosely disaray
Was for like need enforst to disaray:
Who ouertaking him did disaray,
Whom hauing softly disarayd of armes,
And was arayd, or rather disarayd,
Disarmd, disgrast, and inwardly dismayde,
She set beside, laying his head disarm'd
He knew right well, and him attonce disarmd:
Now were disarmd, and did them selues present
They him disarm'd, and spredding on the ground
That all his left side it did quite disarme;
Would him disarme, and treaten shamefully,
And of his weapons did himselfe disarme.
Her to disarme, and with delightfull sport
So weening to haue arm'd him, she did quite disarme.
Offred his seruice to disarme the Knight;
Disarmed all of yron-coted Plate,
Who him disarmed, dissolute, dismaid,
Into a bowre, disarmed for to bee,
The Redcrosse Knight was soone disarmed there,
But the braue Mayd would not disarmed bee,
Hauing her thus disarmed of her shield,
And caused him to be disarmed quight,
Such cruell game my scarmoges disarmes:
Who him besought himselfe to disattyre,
Or vnawares at disauantage found;
Which now him turnd to disauantage deare;
Then enterprised prayse for dread to disauaunce.
As she had seene that day a disauenterous sight.
Doth soonest fall in disauentrous fight,
An hard mishap and disauentrous case
There vnto him betid a disauentrous case.
Then losse of fame in disauentrous field;
Which through great disauenture, or mesprize,
But to and fro at disauenture strayd;
More lucklesse disauentures did amate:
And of my dolefull disauenturous deare:
The name of knighthood he did disauow,
And well disburdened her engrieued brest,
Disburdned her. Their way they forward take
But he that helpe from her against her will discarded.
Could it discerne, though I the mother bee
Which well that valiant courser did discerne;
Art thou now bound? for well mote I discerne
Discerne the hew thereof. He neuer stood,
That none could him discerne, and so went forth to fight.
Or griefe vnknowne, which he could not discerne:
That whether man or monster one could scarse discerne.
That she vneath discerned, whether whether weare.
The weary soule from thence it would discharge;
To Proteus selfe to sue for her discharge:
Discharged of his bow and deadly quar'le,
With garments rent, and haire discheueled,
So dischord oft in Musick makes the sweeter lay.
And as her tongue, so was her hart discided,
That better were in vertues discipled,
That his disciples both desir'd to bee;
And rather needed to be disciplinde
And learnd her discipline of faith and veritie.
For he had charge my discipline to frame,
That she him taught celestiall discipline,
Which them to warlike discipline did trayne,
And them with maystring discipline doth tame,
Let none then blame me, if in discipline
And all the discipline of iustice there him taught.
That rather needes wise read and discipline,
He left his wife; money did loue disclame:
To whom each one his chalenge should disclame,
But ere that wished day his beame disclosd,
And it as oft was from about her wast disclos'd.
Which neuer she before disclosd to none,
The same to wight he neuer wont disclose,
That her perswaded to disclose the breach,
With crime do not it couer, but disclose the same.
Because she knew, she said, I would disclose
And wooe with faire intreatie, to disclose,
This griefes deepe wound I would to thee disclose,
Yet durst she not disclose her fancies wound,
Doe it disclose, to ease your grieued spright:
She vnto him disclosed euery whit,
Which he disclosing, red thus, as the paper spake.
So the faire Britomart hauing disclo'st
That her gay clothes did in discolour die.
A bounch of haires discolourd diuersly:
All in a kirtle of discolourd say
A bunch of haires discolourd diuersly,
Discolour'd like to womanish disguise,
Like a discolourd Snake, whose hidden snares
When her discolourd bow she spreds through heauens hight.
In a discolour'd cote, of straunge disguyse,
Can high aduance his broad discoloured brest,
It plaine, and by the sea discoloured:
And his proud foes discomfit in victorious field.
Discouers to the world discomfited;
Full of discomfort and disquiet plight,
Yet to her Dame him still she discommended,
Abet that virgins cause disconsolate,
As discontent for want of merth or meat;
But he halfe discontent, mote nathelesse
And Paridell though partly discontent
That stryfull hag with gealous discontent
And rayle at them with grudgefull discontent,
Which when their Host perceiu'd, right discontent
Gaue signes of grudge and discontentment vaine:
So hard the discord was to be agreede.
Where he abode, themselues at discord fell,
Their deadly cruell discord to forbeare,
And this misseeming discord meekely lay aside.
Through discord, and the royall throne forlorne:
Duessa discord breedes
For discord harder is to end then to begin.
All which the sad effects of discord sung:
And of the dreadfull discord, which did driue
Is wicked discord, whose small sparkes once blowen
And neuer discord did amongst them fall;
Thereto him Ate stird, new discord to maintaine.
For soone as she them saw to discord set,
Cause of their discord, and so fell debate,
So was their discord by this doome appeased,
Vnmindfull both of that discordfull crew,
And rather stird by his discordfull Dame,
Tho gan to him discouer all his harmes,
Whom if ye please for to discouer plaine,
She list discouer, and of goodly stature;
And all the artes, that subtill wits discouer,
And for what cause; the truth discouer plaine.
They doe to thee in this same dreame discouer.
I will the truth discouer, as it chaunst whylere.
Her weed she then withdrawing, did him discouer,
But day, that doth discouer bad and good,
Through hollow caues, that no man mote discouer
And the high hils Titan discouered,
Now when broad day the world discouered has,
Discouered had the world to heauen wyde,
And from the world that her discouered wide,
Many great Regions are discouered,
That plaine discouered her incontinence,
And all attonce discouered her desire
Therein discouered was, ne ought mote pas,
And passing by, his name discouered,
The which eftsoones discouered, to it drew
Whose face discouered, plainely did expresse
Tho soone as day discouered heauens face
Whom when discouered they had throughly eide,
But when as he discouered had her face,
Discouered had the light to liuing eye,
For doubt to be discouered by his sight,
Ere proofe it tooke, discouered was betymes,
Without discouerie of my thoughts pretence,
But Ate soone discouering his desire,
Me from discouering you my name aright:
Sir knight, that by discouering my estate,
By such discourteous deeds discouering his base kind.
Discouers to the world discomfited;
For day discouers all dishonest wayes,
With temperate aduice discounselled,
By such good meanes he him discounselled,
She was no whit thereby discouraged
From all mens vew, that none might her discoure,
That secretly he saw, yet note discoure:
With faire discourse the euening so they pas:
Then gan the Dwarfe the whole discourse declare,
And goodly gan discourse of many a noble gest.
The large discourse of royall Princes state.
So gan he to discourse the whole debate,
Grew pensiue through that amorous discourse,
A long discourse of his aduentures vaine,
Euery discourse and euery argument,
Thus of their euils as they did discourse,
That dare discourse of so diuine a read,
Till he of tidings mote with him discourse.
The whole discourse of his captiuance sad,
Then gan she to declare the whole discourse
Mongst which he namely did to him discourse,
The which discourse as now I must delay,
At last the caytiue after long discourse,
So long these knights discoursed diuersly,
Of which whilest they discoursed both together,
Diuerse discourses in their way they spent,
Of diuerse things discourses to dilate,
In such discourses they together spent
Discoursing of her dreadfull late distresse,
So diuersly discoursing of their loues,
Was farre forth spent, discoursing diuersly
Discourst his voyage long, according his request.
For thy, she would not in discourteise wise,
Discourteous, disloyall Britomart,
Where that discourteous Dame with scornfull pryde,
A proud discourteous knight:
In which she shew'd, how that discourteous knight
Of a discourteous Knight, who her had reft,
And all the while, that same discourteous Knight,
There he this most discourteous crauen found,
By such discourteous deeds discouering his base kind.
That well appeares in this discourteous knight,
Of fowle discourtesie, vnfit for Knight;
Gan to complaine of great discourtesie,
The foule discourt'sies and vnknightly parts,
The waters fall with difference discreet,
Mishaps are maistred by aduice discrete,
To her faire presence, and discrete behests.
Daunger without discretion to attempt,
Or haue you lost your selfe, and your discretion,
Sir Artegall, without discretion
I will, if please you it discure, assay,
That all regard of shame she had discust,
Disdaind to loose the meed he wonne in fray,
Would not endure to be so vile disdaind,
That I disdain'd amongst mine equall peares
Most lothsom, filthie, foule, and full of vile disdaine.
His gall did grate for griefe and high disdaine,
Pricked with wrath and fiery fierce disdaine,
Her loathly visage viewing with disdaine,
And high disdaine, whenas his soueraine Dame
Inflam'd with scornefull wrath and high disdaine,
And fierce disdaine, to be affronted so,
As Lyon grudging in his great disdaine,
Depart to woods vntoucht, & leaue so proud disdaine?
And her sweet selfe without dread, or disdaine,
In great disdaine, he answerd; Hardy Elfe,
Disdayne he called was, and did disdaine
But with sterne lookes, and stomachous disdaine,
Breathing out wrath, and bellowing disdaine,
For vile disdaine and rancour, which did gnaw
His brother Morgan, prickt with proud disdaine,
Next Archigald, who for his proud disdaine,
With murmurous disdaine doth inly raue,
Stoupes at a flying heron with proud disdaine,
And the great sea puft vp with proud disdaine,
The huge Orsilochus, I swell with great disdaine.
Ythrild with deepe disdaine of his proud threat,
In stead thereof sad sorrow, and disdaine
He vp arose, as halfe in great disdaine,
His sinfull soule with desperate disdaine,
The roaring billowes in their proud disdaine,
He looked round about with sterne disdaine;
Fiercely forth prickt his steed as in disdaine,
Henceforth may not disdaine, that womans hand
With deepe disdaine, and great indignity,
Yet did this trustie Squire with proud disdaine
The hils doe not the lowly dales disdaine;
With proud disdaine did scornefull answere make;
But if through stout disdaine of manly mind,
For high disdaine of such indignity,
Therewith, all fraught with fury and disdaine,
And byting th'earth for very deaths disdaine;
From view of men, and wicked worlds disdaine.
His name is Crudor, who through high disdaine
Vile recreant, know that I doe much disdaine
Did well endure her womanish disdaine,
Wherewith he wroth, and full of proud disdaine,
for loues disdaine decreed.
This was Disdaine, who led that Ladies horse
Prince Arthure ouercomes Disdaine,
He in his necke had set his foote with fell disdaine.
Disdaine and Scorne, I through the world should stray,
Then suffred he Disdaine vp to arise,
Of matchlesse hight, that seem'd th'earth to disdaine;
Of many worst, who with vnkind disdaine
Ne none disdained low to him to lout:
But Sangliere disdained much his doome,
By that proud dame, which her so much disdained,
And trampled downe in dust his thoughts disdained scorne.
Her fawning loue with foule disdainefull spight
She thanked them in her disdainefull wise,
Faire Sir, (said she halfe in disdainefull wise,)
Full of disdainefull wrath, he fierce vprose,
(Sayd he) nor obstinate disdainefull mind,
But she backstarting with disdainefull yre,
And fume in his disdainefull mynd the more,
And downe againe himselfe disdainefully
And entring is; when that disdainfull beast
With foule reproches, and disdainfull spight
From dreaded storme of his disdainfull spight:
(So loue does loath disdainfull nicitee)
Still solemne sad, or still disdainfull coy,
That the disdainfull soule he thence dispatcht,
A dolefull heart with so disdainfull pride;
Loue to conceiue in her disdainfull brest;
And ouerthrew his bowle disdainfully;
In royall heart disdaining to be thrall.
Yet much disdaining vnto him to lout,
Whose shield he beares renuerst, the more to heape disdayn.
For that reprochfull fall right fowly he disdaynd.
And in their raging surquedry disdaynd,
Looking to heauen; for earth she did disdayne,
Disdayne he called was, and did disdaine
As countries cause, and commune foes disdayne.
